SENT.plain: Fat embolism syndrome remains a rare, but potentially life threatening complication of long bone fractures
The true incidence is difficult to assess as many cases remain undiagnosed
Cerebral involvement varies from confusion to encephalopathy with coma and seizures
Clinical symptoms and computed tomography are not always diagnostic, while magnetic resonance imaging is more sensitive in the detection of a suspected brain embolism
Two cases of post-traumatic cerebral fat embolism, manifested by prolonged coma and diffuse cerebral oedema, are presented
The clinical course of the disease as well as the intensive care unit management are discussed
